editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

MOST RESPECTFULLY RECOMMENDED TO THE SERIOUS CONSIDERATION OF THE CITIZENS OF ALL THE UNITED STATES.

div.head: A FEW OBSERVATIONS, &c.

div.p:
THOSE who call to mind the di≈ømal, gloomy ≈øtate of de≈øpondency we were all in at the very time (and for a year or two before) our deputies were framing our now con≈øtitution; the then very ≈ømall hopes, from a variety of ≈øymptoms, that when met, any would be fixed upon, ≈øo as to be generally agree to; the very long and warm di≈øputes and oppo≈øite opinions that happened among≈øt them≈øelves upon that mo≈øt important occa≈øion; the turn, notwith≈øtanding, as it were all at once, of all the ≈øtates pre≈øent, unanimou≈øly to con≈øent to recommend the federal form we have; that the ≈øtates al≈øo ≈øhould ≈øeparately debate as warmly on the acceptance of this form; that at la≈øt all the ≈øtates of the union ≈øhould univer≈øally adopt it; and above all, that this form ≈øhould contain in it≈øelf, extracted from the democratical, the ari≈øtocratical, and the ab≈øolute ≈øy≈øtems, whatever is worth having from each, clear of, and guarded from, all the ≈øhocking and pernicious tendencies each of tho≈øe ≈øy≈øtems are expo≈øed to, and have at times been woefully felt by the ≈øubjects of either: I ≈øay, tho≈øe who weigh the≈øe occurrences alone, (many more as extraordinary might be adduced) and do not perceive a kind fo≈øtering hand of Providence leading the United States to the formation and univer≈øal adoption at la≈øt, of our therefore excellent, and let me add, almo≈øt miraculou≈øly-made con≈øtitution, mu≈øt, I think, be looked upon, if po≈ø≈øible, as
great unbelievers as Mr. Paine ≈øeems to make him≈øelf to be. And here let me notice, en pa≈ø≈øant, a clau≈øe in a letter of this Mr. Paine to our Pre≈øident, dated at Paris but in July la≈øt, in which he ≈øtyles him≈øelf an Anti-Con≈øtitutionali≈øt, not wi≈øhing to be called an Anti-Federali≈øt‚Äî It was only (≈øays he) the ab≈øolute nece≈ø≈øity of ≈øome federal authority extending equally over all the ≈øtates, that an in≈øtrument ≈øo incon≈øi≈øtent as the federal con≈øtitution is, obtained a ≈øuffrage. By this, 'tis plain, he ≈øeems to think our con≈øtitution ought now to be kicked out, being in it≈øelf ≈øo "incon≈øi≈øtent" and not worth "a ≈øuffrage." Whatever may have been Mr. Paine's private thoughts, as he well knew what was brewed and brewing in July la≈øt in Paris again≈øt us, this pa≈ø≈øage carries more the appearance of the malevolence of an in≈øidious enemy wi≈øhing to ≈øtir up divi≈øions among≈øt us to favour the views of France, than any glimp≈øe of the feeling, ≈øympathizing affection of a cordial citizen, what he affects ≈øtill to call him≈øelf.
An idea of perfection ≈øeems to be implanted in our nature, far beyond what the be≈øt man can attain to in practice: our works are like our≈øelves; in the mo≈øt correct, imperfections may be ≈øpied.

q.l: "Thinks what ne'er was, nor is, nor e'er ≈øhall be."

div.p:
Some men of a ≈øtrange turn, fond of laying hold of the lea≈øt ≈ølips, even in the be≈øt plans, to over≈øet them, ≈øeem always for pulling down whatever may be propo≈øed, without ever attempting, them≈øelves, to ≈øub≈øtitute any thing in its place, however ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary that ≈øomething ≈øhould be done. Mr. Paine ≈øeems to be one of the≈øe pull-down politicians. His Common Sen≈øe is a capital work of this ca≈øt, acknowledged to have been well-timed, and of very great ≈øervice to us all in our ≈øtruggle with Great-Britain; but, ≈øtill, not ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary by any means, that we ≈øhould not have ≈øucceeded without it: however, for this we were much obliged to his
pull-down qualities. But has he not now entirely cancelled all this obligation, by endeavouring to pull down our con≈øtitution, and by that means throw us back again into the ≈øame gloomy, de≈øponding ≈øtate we were in before it exi≈øted? Happy for us, he was not here to be concerned in the building it, his talents not laying that way. Pulling down is his forte; here, in my opinion, while he kept to quid valeant humeri, his true political line, none exceeded him: but his Age of Rea≈øon has run his bark bump a≈øhore, and made him appear in as odd a character there, as the bear in the boat, turned ≈øailor.

I confe≈øs I ≈øhould be glad to ≈øee ≈øomething built up by a man ≈øo long employed only in pulling down: it mu≈øt, I think, be a curio≈øity indeed: any ≈øtrong arm, with (I had almo≈øt ≈øaid without) any head, may be ≈øufficient to pull down a fine building; but, to erect a tolerably convenient one, that may be indi≈øpen≈øably nece≈ø≈øary, in its room, a nice hand, guided by a head furni≈øhed with many data in the building way, that Mr. Paine has never hitherto appeared po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of, ≈øeems not to be di≈øpen≈øed with.

Hitherto, in Mr. Paine's various political works of pulling down, he has offered rea≈øons; but his bare ip≈øe dixit he ≈øeems to think ≈øufficient to make us a≈øhamed of our con≈øtitution. But my worthy fellow citizens, under this "≈øo incon≈øi≈øtent" a con≈øtitution, not worth "a ≈øuffrage," according to Mr. Paine, we have been more happy and flouri≈øhing ≈øince its exi≈øtence, now eight years, than any of the be≈øt and mo≈øt tranquil powers in Europe have been for ten times as long. Let us, therefore, be thankful for it; and ≈øuch as it is, a work made by men, not by angels, be contented with it, and join ≈øhoulder to ≈øhoulder in its ≈øupport: not doubting that the ≈øame over-ruling Providence that has favoured us under it hitherto, will not fail us in future, if we do not fail our≈øelves.

The clo≈øer, my friends, you keep to this our heaven-be≈øtowed con≈øtitution, (for, let Mr. Paine think what he
will, I confe≈øs I think it ≈øo) and the more you watch over it, the better and ≈øafer ≈øituation will you and your po≈øterity find your≈øelves in.

q.l: "Still with it≈øelf compar'd, its text peru≈øe,

div.p: The farewell legacy of our long tried, true and tru≈øty friend Pre≈øident Wa≈øhington. For, be per≈øuaded, you will find his fatherly recommendation as good a comment to our con≈øtitution, as "The Mantuan Mu≈øe," ≈øo much recommended by Pope, can be to old Homer.

This intru≈øion, my friends, on your patience, is occa≈øioned by three late public occurrences appearing to me much to affect our con≈øtitution, and, if not properly and timely noticed, their con≈øequences may be very di≈øtre≈ø≈øing, if not fatal. That I might not appear a party man, I kept de≈øignedly ≈øilent till all our elections were over.

They are, fir≈øt, an a≈ø≈øertion in the la≈øt ≈øe≈ø≈øion of congre≈øs, very pertinaciou≈øly maintained by a number of members, that congre≈øs had no right "to enquire into the merits of a foreign treaty."
2dly. The manner our la≈øt election for a chief magi≈øtrate has been carried on.
3dly. The attempt of a foreign mini≈øter to appeal to the people at large.

With regard to the fir≈øt of the≈øe, it will be fully ≈øufficient, in my opinion, to contra≈øt the power given by the con≈øtitution to the pre≈øident and ≈øenate united, with the general power, given by the ≈øame con≈øtitution, to the congre≈øs, (of which the repre≈øentatives are a part) to ≈øee, not only the danger, but the weak foundation of that a≈ø≈øertion. However, a few remarks ≈øhall be added.

q.p: The pre≈øident ≈øhall have power, by and with the con≈øent of the ≈øenate, to make treaties; provided 2-3ds of the ≈øenate pre≈øent concur.
The congre≈øs ≈øhall have power to provide for the general welfare of the United States.

div.p: Nothing appears to me ea≈øier than that each of the≈øe powers may do the duty enjoined, without cla≈øhing or interfering in the lea≈øt with each other. Let the pre≈øident and ≈øenate make a treaty as directed, without the congre≈øs interfering. Let the congre≈øs, when a treaty is made, provide for it, if they think it not contrary to the welfare of the United States. Here we find the congre≈øs have nothing to do with the making of a treaty, (and very rightly, from the delay and variety of ob≈øtructions that would probably happen in ≈øo numerous a body) but, when made by the pre≈øident and ≈øenate, and application is had to them to provide for it, can any per≈øon then think his bu≈øine≈øs excluded entirely from the direction given them, "to provide for the general welfare of the United States;" but that they are ≈øtill obliged to make ≈øuch provi≈øion, even if they are per≈øuaded that it is extremely dangerous to, if not de≈øtructive of that general welfare?

Many good rea≈øons may be given for their not being concerned in the making of a treaty; but not one, I imagine, that when made, at all events, whether they think it for, or not, for the general welfare of the United States, they ought ≈øtill to provide for it. This appears to me ≈øo plain a ca≈øe, that there does not ≈øeem occa≈øion to call in the ≈øpirit of our con≈øtitution as an arbitrator; but yet let us call it in, in ≈øettling this point, allowed to be of the utmo≈øt importance. We are all made to believe that the three departments of our government, are mutual checks on each other, and that in tho≈øe checks lies our great ≈øecurity. This is what I call the ≈øpirit of our con≈øtitution, and accordingly, even in this bu≈øine≈øs of treaty-making, the ≈øenate is a check on the pre≈øident. But where is the check upon the pre≈øident and ≈øenate united, ≈øhould they combine and act treacherou≈øly, if this new doctrine ≈øhould take place? Is there no danger here? No need for any father check? A treaty, when made, is a ≈øupreme law of the land. Some trading nations would very probably, to bring about a treaty to
their liking with the United States, give very large douceurs. I hope our pre≈øident and ≈øenate will always be an uncorruptible body; but hi≈øtory tells us that con≈øuls and ≈øenates have had clammy fingers: what has been, may be again. Thank heaven, our con≈øtitution does not de≈øert us even here. We mu≈øt be all rogues, all rotten, before we can be ruined: when that indeed is the ca≈øe, there is no help for us; the body politic, like the natural body, mu≈øt be ≈øoon after entirely di≈ø≈øolved. They are both pa≈øt cure.

Here let me declare my concern, that the congre≈øs ≈øent for the papers relative to the making of the Briti≈øh treaty. This ≈øtep appears to me to have been unnece≈ø≈øary, as the treaty it≈øelf was before them, a ≈øufficient ground to form their judgment upon. But the a≈øtoni≈øhment to hear it a≈ø≈øerted, that they had no right to enquire into its merits, mu≈øt have irritated many. Heat begets heat; and one part over≈øtretching one way, often fires the other to do the like their way. This is human nature collectively, as well as individually.

I confe≈øs my≈øelf one, though no favourer of the Briti≈øh treaty while pending, made very happy, at hearing that ≈øo many members, who had expre≈ø≈øed them≈øelves again≈øt it in the hou≈øe, had ≈øacrificed their private opinions to the peace of the public. But, indeed, I never at any time thought that treaty of ≈øuch moment, that it ≈øhould be refu≈øed to be provided for by our repre≈øentatives.

Farther, what is here ≈øaid, is intended to prove the con≈øtitutional right the congre≈øs have to con≈øider the merits of a treaty; not by any means to in≈øinuate, that upon every bad bargain, they ≈øhould deny to provide for a treaty. No! But upon the mo≈øt glaring, trying occa≈øions, like the Briti≈øh parliament (fas e≈øt et ab ho≈øte doceri) to exerci≈øe that right: this cau≈øes no interruption among≈øt them in making their treaties with foreign nations, who know they claim ≈øuch a right, and will exerci≈øe it when they find it ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary. What
rea≈øonable objection can they then have to our doing it only on ≈øuch occa≈øions?

I am aware that foreign nations, as well as bad pre≈øidents and ≈øenates, would wi≈øh to ≈øee no po≈ø≈øibility of any after reckoning; but that the repre≈øentatives of the people ≈øhould be obliged to provide for any treaty laid before them, whatever may be its merits, duration or tendency. But our con≈øtitution provides an ample remedy in ≈øuch ca≈øes, if the people but do their parts. Send hone≈øt, firm men, of good ≈øound common ≈øen≈øe, that can judge when it will be ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary to apply that remedy; when not.

Still pardon me, my worthy friends, for thinking the manner of carrying on the la≈øt election for our chief magi≈øtrate, very objectionable, and, if continued, ≈øeems in its tendency, not only calculated to foment and keep up heats and animo≈øities among≈øt us, but in no long time, I am afraid, to over≈øet our union, or ≈øplit and ≈øhiver us into many different governments; and if we once begin to divide, no one can fore≈øee the end of it.

Our con≈øtitution ≈øays, Each ≈øtate ≈øhall appoint, in ≈øuch manner as the legi≈ølature thereof may direct, a number of electors, equal to the whole number of ≈øenators and repre≈øentatives to which the ≈øtate may be entitled in the congre≈øs: but no ≈øenator, or repre≈øentative, or per≈øon holding an office of tru≈øt or profit under the United States, ≈øhall be appointed an elector.

q.p:
The electors ≈øhall meet in their re≈øpective ≈øtates, and [≈øhall] vote by ballot for two per≈øons, one of whom, at lea≈øt, ≈øhall not be an inhabitant of the ≈øame ≈øtate with them≈øelves; and they ≈øhall make a li≈øt of all the per≈øons voted for, and of the number of votes for each; which li≈øt they ≈øhall ≈øign and certify, and tran≈ømit, ≈øealed, to the ≈øeat of the government of the United States, directed to the pre≈øident of the ≈øenate. The pre≈øident of the ≈øenate ≈øhall, in the pre≈øence of the ≈øenate and hou≈øe of repre≈øentatives, open all the certificates, and the votes ≈øhall then be
counted. The per≈øon having the greate≈øt number of votes ≈øhall be the pre≈øident, if ≈øuch number be a majority of the whole number of electors appointed; and if there be more than one who have ≈øuch majority, and have an equal number of votes, then the hou≈øe of repre≈øentatives ≈øhall immediately chu≈øe, by ballot, one of them for pre≈øident; and if no per≈øon have a majority, then, from the five highe≈øt on the li≈øt, the ≈øaid hou≈øe ≈øhall, in like manner, chu≈øe the pre≈øident. But in chu≈øing the pre≈øident, the votes ≈øhall be taken by ≈øtates, the repre≈øentatives from each ≈øtate having one vote; a quorum for this purpo≈øe ≈øhall con≈øi≈øt of a member or members from two-thirds of the ≈øtates: and a majority of all the ≈øtates ≈øhall be nece≈ø≈øary to a choice. In every ca≈øe, after the choice of the pre≈øident, the per≈øon having the greate≈øt number of votes of the electors, ≈øhall be the vice-pre≈øident; but if there ≈øhould remain two or more, who have equal votes, the ≈øenate ≈øhall chu≈øe from them, by ballot, the vice-pre≈øident.
The congre≈øs may determine the time of chu≈øing the electors, and the day on which they ≈øhall give their votes; which day ≈øhall be THE SAME throughout the United States.

No per≈øon, except a natural born citizen, or a citizen of the United States at the time of the adoption of this con≈øtitution, ≈øhall be eligible to the office of pre≈øident; neither ≈øhall any per≈øon be eligible to that office, who ≈øhall not have attained the age of thirty-five years, and been fourteen years a re≈øident within the United States.

div.p:
Now, my fellow citizens, ≈øuppo≈øe we read the latter part of the fir≈øt of the≈øe clau≈øes, thus: But NO PERSON holding an office of tru≈øt or profit under the United States, ≈øhall be appointed an elector. Do not the words, "no per≈øon," in them≈øelves, as compleatly include the ≈øenator and repre≈øentative, without their being particularly named, as with? Therefore, unle≈øs
the≈øe words, "≈øenator or repre≈øentative," are taken di≈øtinctly and ≈øeparately, as the characteri≈øtic of a legi≈ølative capacity, they are altogether nugatory and ≈øuperfluous. Whoever attends to the ≈øtyle of the con≈øtitution, will, I believe, find no where el≈øe in it, ≈øuch an unnecessary redundancy. Therefore, as it appears to me, ≈øenator and repre≈øentative being to be under≈øtood in the legi≈ølative character of each, and ONLY ≈øo, they are both excluded, by the intention of the con≈øtitution it≈øelf, from being electors; for, had it been de≈øigned that any a≈ø≈øembly ≈øhould have appointed the electors from among them≈øelves, preci≈øion required that the words from among them≈øelves, or others of like ≈øignification, ≈øhould have been in≈øerted: as no ≈øuch are, when they ≈øeem ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary, no claim, e≈øpecially one of ≈øuch moment, ought to be a≈ø≈øumed from an, at lea≈øt, equivocal expre≈ø≈øion. Be≈øides, to a public body appointed to fix upon another public body, upon a bu≈øine≈øs of the greate≈øt importance, ≈øurely it mu≈øt ≈øeem awkward and indelicate, for the fir≈øt public body to chu≈øe out of them≈øelves, the whole, or 7-8ths of the other, upon an authority ≈øo doubtful and di≈øputable, as not preci≈øely and clearly giving them leave to appoint a ≈øingle one.

Again; the electors for a pre≈øident being equal, in every ≈øtate, to all the members in each of tho≈øe ≈øtates, (≈øenators and repre≈øentatives) taken together, the electors ≈øeem to be left to be appointed by the repre≈øentatives ONLY, (they being peculiarly the public's vicegerents) in order that our three departments of government, the pre≈øident, ≈øenate, and repre≈øentative, might be ALL of a piece, ALL the choice of the people; and, therefore, ≈øuch electors, when thus cho≈øen to fix upon a pre≈øident, ought to be as free, un≈øhackled, and independent, as the members of the a≈ø≈øemblies them≈øelves, who are cho≈øen in each ≈øtate, to repre≈øent their re≈øpective citizens at large. This, I think, cannot be denied; and, therefore, the elector, who, antecedent to his appointment, has engaged to vote for any particular per≈øon,
